summary.abstract: This article examines the classical epistolary novel preserved in the Arabic version of Salim Abu-l-'Ala', focusing on the correspondence between Alexander and Aristotle. Grignaschi traces the textual tradition through multiple manuscript sources, particularly two Syrian-Egyptian manuscripts completed in the 8th century of the Islamic calendar, establishing their genealogical relationship and independence from one another. The study identifies sixteen pieces of correspondence, three of which were previously known, and demonstrates connections to earlier Arabic works such as al-Hikmat al-halida and the Sirr-al-asrar (Secrets of Secrets). Through careful collation of manuscripts held in Istanbul, Vatican, and European libraries, the author reconstructs the literary history of this important Greco-Arabic text and its transmission in medieval Islamic scholarship.
